para.paratext: Extrinsic or parol contemporaneous evidence is inadmissible to contradict or vary the terms of a valid written instrument. The term “extrinsic” means from sources outside the written instrument.[1] The term “parol” means oral or verbal evidence.[2] The purpose of the parol evidence body of rules is to establish the finality of written contracts between two parties in privity. Thus, once two parties have documented their agreements in writing, in general, Georgia law deems their pre-contractual negotiations irrelevant. The Georgia courts state the rule as follows: “the parol evidence rule bars any attempt to contradict, vary or supplement the consideration stated in an integrated contract.”[3]

This “rule,” which is really a collection of principles, existed in Georgia long before the first Code.[4] The parol evidence rule is substantive law in Georgia.[5] However, it is traditional to consider it in the area of evidence. If it were a rule of evidence, then it could be waived by failure to object and the admitted evidence would be entitled to probative value. In addition to the probative value of the evidence, the substantive law aspect of the rule is important in conflict of law problems, federal diversity cases, and rulings on the pleadings.

The parol evidence rule, since often considered a matter of substantive law rather than evidence, is not included in the Federal Rules of Evidence. In federal courts, federal common law applies, except where Georgia law furnishes the rule of decision.[6] The rule, in a matter of first impression, has been deemed not to apply to criminal proceedings. The Court of Appeals held that while in a civil context, it is important to bring finality to an agreement, the purpose of a criminal trial is to determine if a defendant is guilty of the crimes charged, and, in a theft by taking case, testimony regarding the makings of a loan used for purposes other than those discussed during the negotiations were relevant and admissible in the criminal trial despite the merger clause included in the agreement.[7]
Abrams v. Massell, 262 Ga. App. 761, 586 S.E.2d 435 (2003); Capital City Bank v. Jones, 333 Ga. App. 126, 775 S.E.2d 608 (2015).

Rogers v. Atkinson, 1 Ga. 12, 1846 WL 1136 (1846), cited in Lyon v. Patterson, 138 Ga. App. 816, 227 S.E.2d 423 (1976), setting out the history of the rule in Georgia. Also quoted in Weintraub v. Cobb Bank & Trust Co., 249 Ga. 148, 288 S.E.2d 553 (1982).

The parol evidence rule is clearly a rule of substantive law in Georgia. Lyon v. Patterson, 138 Ga. App. 816, 227 S.E.2d 423 (1976); Craig v. Citizens and Southern Nat. Bank, 142 Ga. App. 474, 236 S.E.2d 166 (1977).

Simpson v. U.S., 172 U.S. 372, 19 S. Ct. 222, 43 L. Ed. 482 (1899); Northern Assur. Co. of London v. Grand View Bldg. Ass'n, 183 U.S. 308, 22 S. Ct. 133, 46 L. Ed. 213 (1902); Ford v. Luria Steel & Trading Corp., 192 F.2d 880 (8th Cir. 1951); Rock-Ola Mfg. Corp. v. Wertz, 282 F.2d 208 (4th Cir. 1960); Farmers Mut. Hail Ins. Co. of Iowa v. Fox Turkey Farms, Inc., 301 F.2d 697 (8th Cir. 1962).
